author: By Zachary Small
title: Home of Brooklyn Abolitionists Receives Landmark Status
description: Twenty years of campaigning to preserve a Downtown rowhouse ends in success for neighborhood activists.
content: After a 20-year effort by activists to save it from destruction, a rowhouse in Downtown Brooklyn received landmark status Tuesday for its connection to the antislavery movement of the 1800s.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elaine Yu
title: Hunting Rats, Defending Democracy: Hong Kong’s Local Leaders Under Fire
description: District councilors typically tended to mundane matters like pest control and new bus stops. Now, they’re the last line of defense in keeping the city’s pro-democracy opposition alive.
content: HONG KONG — Some days, Cathy Yau wanders down dark alleys looking for rats to poison. Other days, she helps food banks deliver meals to older people. Often her phone rings with calls from constituents: neighbors asking about their rights during a police stop-and-frisk, or how to best navigate the city’s welfare bureaucracy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carol Rosenberg
title: Judge Postpones Guantánamo Court Appearances, Citing Pandemic
description: A military judge who was to travel to Guantánamo Bay this week ruled that the health risks the base posed were reason enough to delay the arraignments of three prisoners.
content: WASHINGTON — A military judge on Tuesday indefinitely postponed the arraignment of three prisoners at Guantánamo Bay who were scheduled to make their first court appearance in 17 years of detention, finding that the coronavirus pandemic made it too risky to travel to the Navy base.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gillian R. Brassil and Kevin Draper
title: These Women Were N.F.L. ‘Firsts.’ They’re Eager for Company.
description: Two women will coach the Tampa Bay Buccaneers in this year’s Super Bowl, a milestone in the N.F.L.’s gender diversity efforts. Women in football hope their presence quickly stops being noteworthy.
content: The football pioneers arrived quickly over the past year: the first woman to coach in a Super Bowl, the first woman chosen to officiate a Super Bowl, the first Black woman to be named a full-time coach in the N.F.L.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy Engle
title: Lesson of the Day: ‘Myanmar’s Coup, Explained’

content: Featured Article: “Myanmar’s Coup, Explained” by Russell Goldman

title: As the Tennis Party in Australia Begins, an Uncertain Year Awaits

content: MELBOURNE, Australia — By sheer force of will, professional tennis inched toward normalcy this week, with a flurry of events in a country that has managed to nearly smother the coronavirus.

title: June Rose Bellamy, Adventurous Burmese Princess, Dies at 88
description: She traveled the world, hosted a TV show in the Philippines, married a dictator (out of patriotism, she said) and, among other things, opened a cooking school in Italy.
content: Her father was an Australian bookie and adventurer. Her mother was a princess, a scion of the Konbaung dynasty, the last royal family of Burma (now Myanmar). They met while betting on the racetracks in Rangoon (now Yangon), the capital, and it was she who proposed.

title: A Mysterious, Lethal Chimp Disease Is Linked to a Human Illness
description: Deaths at a Sierra Leone sanctuary that stumped people for 15 years have now been linked to a bacterium that seems to cause similar ailments in humans.
content: Chimpanzees had been dying mysteriously at the Tacugama sanctuary in Sierra Leone for a decade or so by 2016 when Tony Goldberg set to work on figuring out why.

title: Nearly half of U.S. states allow teachers to get shots.

title: After Coup, Myanmar Military Charges Aung San Suu Kyi With Obscure Infraction
description: The move against the deposed civilian leader was a curious coda to the army’s rapid dismantling of the country’s nascent democracy.
content: Two days after Myanmar’s military seized power in a coup, the scope of its formal allegations against the country’s civilian leader, Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, are taking shape: She is accused of illegally importing at least 10 walkie-talkies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tiffany Hsu
title: Super Bowl Commercials: To Address or Avoid the Pandemic?
description: The year’s biggest TV advertising day will include nods to a difficult time — and Dolly Parton.
content: Some of the biggest players on Super Bowl Sunday won’t be wearing helmets. They’re the company executives and ad makers who will be monitoring the reaction to the big-budget commercials that will have their television debuts before an expected audience of 100 million viewers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Roberts
title: Eugenio Martínez, Last of the Watergate Burglars, Dies at 98
description: A hero to exiles from Castro’s Cuba, he was the only person other than Richard Nixon to receive a presidential pardon in the scandal.
content: Eugenio Martínez, the last surviving Watergate burglar and the only figure in the scandal besides Richard M. Nixon to be granted a presidential pardon, died on Saturday in Minneola, Fla. He was 98.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Shift Toward Clean Cars
description: How big automakers are abandoning resistance
content: Toyota, Fiat Chrysler and several other big automakers said this week they would no longer try to block California from setting its own strict fuel-economy standards. The move signaled that the auto industry as a whole is now ready to work with President Biden on one of his main efforts to reduce greenhouse gas emissions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alida Becker
title: From Turkey to China to Norway, These Novels Take You Back in Time
description: A batch of fresh translations speaks to the universality of the human experience.
content: “Whatever you do, whatever you call your form of government, you end up with a sultan at the top.” When LOVE IN THE DAYS OF REBELLION (Europa, 496 pp., paper, $19) was first published in Turkey in 2001, Ahmet Altan, the author who gave those words to one of his characters, was a free man and Recep Tayyip Erdogan, the former mayor of Istanbul, was just beginning his rise to national prominence. But Brendan Freely and Yelda Turedi’s translation of Altan’s novel arrives under very different circumstances, with President Erdogan firmly in power and Altan behind bars, a political prisoner accused of crimes against the state for his activities as a journalist. Reading the newly released second volume of Altan’s Ottoman Quartet suggests that the death of his country’s old empire may shed light on the new ones that followed.
source.name: The New York Times

content: PARIS — Léna Situations shot to fame in France by sharing fashion advice and tips for living a positive life with millions of her followers on social media.

title: Jim Justice, a G.O.P. Governor, on Why Biden Needs to ‘Go Big’ on Covid Aid
description: The governor of West Virginia, who supported a bigger relief bill than Senator Joe Manchin, a Democrat, initially did, spoke with us about government spending, Covid-19 vaccinations and climate policy.
content: The odds that Democrats will succeed in passing a large economic rescue package received a boost this week from an unexpected source: Gov. Jim Justice of West Virginia, a Republican. Mr. Justice said on Monday, in back-to-back interviews with CNN and MSNBC, that Congress should “go big” and not worry about the federal deficit.

title: Lloyd Austin ramps up the fight against right-wing extremism within the military.

title: ‘I May Destroy You’ Is Shut Out by Golden Globes
description: Michaela Coel’s standout series was the most puzzling omission by the Hollywood Foreign Press Association, which offered something familiar after a year of chaos: inconsistency.
content: Unpredictability is the biggest weakness of the TV portion of the Golden Globes, and also its greatest strength. You can usually count on the Globes’s handful of voters to make some baffling choices as well as to celebrate some deserving but obscure nominees that the Emmys overlook.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Soloski
title: All the World’s a Screen? They’re Used to It
description: Is theater even theater when you watch it on your laptop? Ask the artists who’ve blurred the boundaries between live and filmed performance for years.
content: About a year ago, when such things were possible, a friend and I bought cheap, same-day tickets to a preview of “West Side Story,” directed by the Belgian auteur Ivo van Hove. Our assigned seats were in the second row of the orchestra, on the extreme left, below the lip of the stage. Which means that we saw most of the performance via the 30-foot-tall LED display at the back.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Thomas
title: After a Rocky Start, Novavax Vaccine Could Be Here by Summer

Navalny.

title: Len Dawson Is Better Than Patrick Mahomes: A Sentimental Dad’s Argument

title: The QAnon Delusion Has Not Loosened Its Grip
description: Millions of Americans continue to actively participate in multiple conspiracy theories. Why?
content: A conspiracy theory promulgated by Donald Trump, the loser of the 2020 presidential election, has gripped American politics since Nov. 3. It has been willingly adopted by millions of his followers, as well as by a majority of Republican members of Congress — 145 to 108 — and by thousands of Republican state and local officials, all of whom have found it expedient to capitulate to the fantastical claim that the election was stolen by the Democratic Party, its officeholders, operatives and supporters.

content: Nearly eight months ago, Scott M. Stringer stood in Brooklyn before an angry, unsettled gathering to memorialize the death of George Floyd. The best way to honor him, Mr. Stringer said, was to send a clear message to City Hall: “It’s time to defund the N.Y.P.D. now.”

author: By Gretchen Reynolds
title: Can Exercise Make You More Creative?
description: To spur innovation and ideas, try taking a walk.
content: If you often exercise, there’s a good chance you also tend to be more creative, according to an interesting new study of the links between physical activity and imagination. It finds that active people come up with more and better ideas during tests of their inventiveness than people who are relatively sedentary, and suggests that if we wish to be more innovative, we might also want to be movers and shakers.
source.name: The New York Times

Trump for inciting a violent “attack on our workplace” that threatened the peaceful transition of power.

title: President Biden pays his respects to Brian Sicknick, the officer who died from injuries from the Capitol riot.

title: The GOAT’s a Hog. Still, I Want Tom Brady to Win.
description: In the Super Bowl, Americans need a show of superheroic strength.
content: If you’re a fan of any team in the National Football League other than the New England Patriots, you spent much of the past two decades hating the quarterback Tom Brady, by which I really mean fearing and resenting Tom Brady, because he and the Pats won so damned much that they were bound to throttle your team at some point, probably on their way to yet another Super Bowl appearance and victory. It just wasn’t fair.

title: Rennie Davis, ‘Chicago Seven’ Antiwar Activist, Dies at 80
description: The trial arising from the “police riot” at the 1968 convention thrust him into the spotlight. He later became an unlikely spokesman for a teenage guru.
content: Rennie Davis, who lived out one of the more quixotic journeys of the 1960s generation when he went from leading opponent of the Vietnam War, as a convicted member of the Chicago Seven, to spokesman for a teenage Indian guru, died on Tuesday at his home in Berthoud, Colo. He was 80.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephanie Goodman
title: Questlove’s ‘Summer of Soul’ Wins at Sundance
description: The documentary took home two prizes while “Coda” won several honors for its fictional tale of a hearing teenager in a deaf family.
content: A documentary about the 1969 Harlem Cultural Festival, often called the Black Woodstock, and a feature about a hearing daughter in a deaf family took top honors Tuesday night at the first virtual edition of the Sundance Film Festival.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Thrush
title: Analysis: Fights over Greene and Cheney are bad news for a weakened McCarthy, less of a problem for McConnell.
description: The ugly fights over the two congresswomen proved that Representative Kevin McCarthy, the Republican leader, remains trapped under former President Donald J. Trump’s shadow.
content: On Wednesday, Democrats hurtled toward a Thursday vote on stripping committee assignments from Representative Marjorie Taylor Greene, Republican of Georgia, over comments and social media posts promoting QAnon conspiracies and anti-Jewish tropes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Constant Méheut
title: Court Faults France Over ‘Ecological Damage’ From Its Emissions Levels
description: A Paris court said the French state had failed to meet its commitments on greenhouse gas emissions. The lawsuit is among a growing number of such legal actions internationally.
content: PARIS — A French court ruled on Wednesday that France had caused “ecological damage” by insufficiently reducing its greenhouse gas emissions, a landmark decision that environmentalists said they hoped would be more than merely symbolic as such cases are increasingly brought to courts internationally.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Horowitz
title: Mario Draghi Gets Nod to Form New Government and Guide Italy Out of Crisis
description: The sudden ascent of the man credited with helping save the euro was a pipe dream for Italians frustrated with a coalition paralyzed by ideological schisms and incompetence.
content: ROME — Mario Draghi, the former head of the European Central Bank who is largely credited with helping to save the euro, accepted a mandate from Italy’s president on Wednesday to try and form a new unity government that would guide the country out of the pandemic and through economic recovery.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: Superspreader Sunday?
description: And what else you need to know today.
content: Coronavirus cases in the U.S. have surged after almost every major holiday of the past year, including Memorial Day, Labor Day, Thanksgiving and Christmas. This weekend brings another major holiday, even if it’s not an official one: Super Bowl Sunday. And there is reason to worry that it will turn into Superspreader Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kara Swisher
title: As Jeff Bezos Takes Off, Meet His Earthbound Successor
description: His loyal lieutenant will take Amazon’s helm as the company faces ever-growing scrutiny.
content: Who, you might ask at this moment, is Andy Jassy?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brent McDonald and Alfonso Flores Bermúdez
title: After Hurricane’s Devastation, a Dilemma in Nicaragua: Rebuild or Relocate?
description: A wedge of ocean the width of a football field now cuts through the middle of their town, leaving villagers with an anguishing question.
content: HAULOVER, Nicaragua — When the leaders of an Indigenous Miskito village returned to their homes days after Hurricane Iota struck last November, they found their lush community in Nicaragua’s northeast laid to ruin — and the coastline itself transformed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Prevost
title: House Hunting on St. Croix: A Converted Sugar Mill With Sea Views
description: The U.S. Virgin Islands, heavily dependent on tourism, saw their three-year economic recovery stall amid the pandemic. But there is still plenty of life in the housing market.
content: This five-bedroom property claims nearly five hilltop acres on the mountainous northwest end of St. Croix, in the U.S. Virgin Islands. The 5,545-square-foot house is built in and around an 18th-century sugar mill, though most of it was constructed of concrete and stone in the early 1990s, after Hurricane Hugo demolished a more modest wood home on the site.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Goldstein
title: Pension Funds Are Mixed or Mum on More Cash for Apollo
description: California’s huge public retirement system, for one, offered only cautious support after new disclosures of financial ties between the firm’s chief, Leon Black, and Jeffrey Epstein.
content: When investors in Apollo Global Management learned last week that the firm’s chief executive had paid $158 million to the registered sex offender Jeffrey Epstein, they hardly blinked.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: Hooking Readers on Classical Music, Five Minutes at a Time
description: Drawing on the passion of experts, a Culture desk series has doubled its audience for the genre.
content: Mark Hamill was spellbound by a Mozart composition, but he couldn’t remember its name. The haunting choral masterpiece played near the end of the Broadway production of “Amadeus” more than 40 years ago, in which he performed the title role.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stefanos Chen
title: The Downside to Life in a Supertall Tower: Leaks, Creaks, Breaks
description: 432 Park, one of the wealthiest addresses in the world, faces some significant design problems, and other luxury high-rises may share its fate.
content: The nearly 1,400-foot tower at 432 Park Avenue, briefly the tallest residential building in the world, was the pinnacle of New York’s luxury condo boom half a decade ago, fueled largely by foreign buyers seeking discretion and big returns.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Firshein
title: Help! I’m Vaccinated, but What Do I Need to Know to Protect Others?
description: A reader plans to hop on a flight two weeks after her second shot of the coronavirus vaccine to see much-missed grandchildren, but wonders what health and safety precautions she still needs to take.
content: I’ve had my first vaccination shot and plan to book a flight to California two weeks after my second one. Like so many others, I have not seen my grandchildren for more than 15 months, during which time the baby became a toddler and the preschooler became a young boy. Now that some of us are getting successfully vaccinated and are planning on flying to see our families, I have a few questions that I’m hoping you can clear up. Margot
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian X. Chen and Kevin Roose
title: Are Private Messaging Apps the Next Misinformation Hot Spot?
description: Telegram and Signal, the encrypted services that keep conversations confidential, are increasingly popular. Our tech columnists discuss whether this could get ugly.
content: Encrypted messaging apps, which protect the privacy of online conversations, were once special tools used primarily by people working in professions where confidentiality was prized, like law, journalism and politics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Moore
title: In the Ozarks, the Pandemic Threatens a Fragile Musical Tradition
description: The older fiddlers and rhythm guitar players don’t rely on sheet music, so their weekly jam sessions — now on hiatus — are critical to passing their technique to the next generation.
content: McCLURG, Mo. — In an abandoned general store along a nearly deserted country road, Alvie Dooms, 90, and Gordon McCann, 89, played rhythm guitar. Nearly a dozen more musicians, many of them also older adults, joined in on fiddle, mandolin, banjo and upright bass. Their tunes had names like “Last Train Home,” “Pig Ankle Rag” and “Arkansas Traveler.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: 5 Minutes That Will Make You Love String Quartets
description: Listen as our writers and some of our favorite artists share music of intimacy, intensity and joy.
content: In the past, we’ve chosen the five minutes or so we would play to make our friends fall in love with classical music, the piano, opera, the cello, Mozart, 21st-century composers, the violin, Baroque music, sopranos, Beethoven and the flute.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Azi Paybarah
title: Three Skiers Found Dead After Avalanche in Colorado, Officials Say
description: The skiers were found Wednesday under more than 20 feet of avalanche debris, the San Juan County Office of Emergency Management said.
content: Three backcountry skiers in southwestern Colorado were found dead on Wednesday, two days after the group they were traveling with triggered a large avalanche, officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Egill Bjarnason
title: Iceland Has a Request for Disney+: More Icelandic, Please
description: Disney brought its streaming service to Iceland last year. Now, the country’s education minister has sent a letter of complaint over the lack of Icelandic dubbing and subtitling.
content: REYKJAVIK, Iceland — Iceland, like much of the world, has embraced Disney’s popular streaming service, Disney+, since it arrived there late last year, with characters from Mickey Mouse to Mulan now available to watch on demand in homes across the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sima
title: These Lizards Have a Hot Trick to Escape Hungry Snakes
description: On some Japanese islands where lizards live, the ones that fear predators have higher body temperatures that help them run faster.
content: Masami Hasegawa was just an undergraduate student when he first visited the Izu Islands of Japan in 1977. Every year since, he has taken the eight-hour ferry ride from Tokyo southeast to this cluster of volcanic islands to pursue a passion he has had since childhood: catching lizards.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Prevost
title: Madison, Conn.: A Welcoming Town With Long Stretches of Beach
description: The shoreline town, which has seen an influx of buyers during the pandemic, has been praised by new arrivals as ‘neither too hip, nor too boring.’
content: About a year ago, Margaret Muir, an agent with William Pitt Sotheby’s International Realty in Madison, Conn., was bemoaning the state’s lackluster housing market and a population on the decline. “More people were leaving my beautiful Connecticut than moving in,” she said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giovanni Russonello
title: How Trump’s Defense Is Coming Together
description: The impeachment trial jousting has begun: This is your morning tip sheet.
content: Trump’s lawyers prepare two lines of defense, while Republicans in Congress mull their next move. It’s Wednesday, and this is your politics tip sheet. Sign up here to get On Politics in your inbox every weekday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya Phillips
title: ‘Earwig and the Witch’ Review: Domestic Incantations
description: A headstrong orphan girl gets taken in by a witch and a demon in this computer-animated film from Studio Ghibli.
content: A strong-willed young heroine, a witch, a talking cat, cute magical minions: “Earwig and the Witch” has many of the familiar qualities of a Studio Ghibli film. And yet Ghibli’s latest, directed by Goro Miyazaki, the son of the famed animator Hayao Miyazaki, uses ingredients from the tried-and-true Ghibli recipe while serving a film that lacks the heart the studio has always brought to its best.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Johnny Diaz, Patricia Mazzei, Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs and Michael H. Keller
title: Killing of F.B.I. Agents Comes Amid Explosion of Child Sex Abuse Reports
description: As tips about online child sexual abuse have spiked, the F.B.I. is investigating the case of a Florida technology contractor who the bureau said shot two agents executing a search warrant at his apartment.
content: SUNRISE, Fla. — While investigating a tip late last year about a man suspected of possessing child sexual abuse imagery, deputies from the sheriff’s office in Walton County, Fla., worried that executing a search warrant might be dangerous: The man lived in an isolated area, kept strange hours and was thought to have a secret bunker.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Oscar Lopez
title: Mexico Arrests Police Officers Over Massacre
description: The arrest of government agents for the brutal killing of 19 people, including several migrants, is a rare instance of local police being charged with such a crime.
content: MEXICO CITY — Authorities in Mexico have arrested a dozen police officers for the massacre of 19 people, including several migrants, an incident which the country’s interior minister said Wednesday was part of a larger pattern of migrant abuse at the hands of government agents.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brooks Barnes and Nicole Sperling
title: Netflix Dominates Golden Globes Nods, With ‘Mank’ and ‘The Crown’ Leading the Way
description: The streaming service received a jaw-dropping 42 nominations, in a year where almost every film in contention has been released online. Three women were nominated for best director, a first.
content: Golden Globe nominators pulled David Fincher’s sleepy “Mank” and the revenge-driven “Promising Young Woman” deeper into the Oscar race on Wednesday, while embracing female directors, reacting somewhat coolly to Black ensemble films and, as ever, sprinkling honors on a wide range of stars, from first-timers to living legends.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: Parrish Art Museum Announces New Director
description: Kelly Taxter, a curator at the Jewish Museum, will lead the Parrish beginning in March.
content: The Parrish Art Museum, which showcases work by Long Island artists, announced Wednesday that Kelly Taxter will be its next director. She succeeds Terrie Sultan, who helmed the museum for 12 years before stepping down in June.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rob Tannenbaum
title: Celeste, a Young Singer With an Old Soul, Makes Her Move
description: The 26-year-old British musician writes songs infused with experiences, feelings and coincidences. Her buzzy debut album arrived last week.
content: The best way to learn about Celeste, the rising British soul singer and songwriter with a gift for channeling earlier eras, is to ask about her songs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Ellentuck
title: ‘This Kid’s Special’: Candace Parker Owned L.A. From Day 1
description: Parker, long the face of the Los Angeles Sparks, opened her W.N.B.A. career with a statement game. Its message has held up for 13 seasons and counting: She deserved the hype.
content: Candace Parker’s storied tenure with the Los Angeles Sparks is over. On Monday, she signed a two-year deal with the Chicago Sky, one of the most shocking decisions ever in W.N.B.A. free agency. Parker, who was drafted No. 1 over all by the Sparks in 2008, is headed back home, not far from where she grew up in Naperville, Ill.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Thomas and Rebecca Robbins
title: Vaccine News Gives Hope for Spring, if Enough People Get the Shots
description: New data from several vaccine trials offer positive signs, but many public health experts say emerging variants mean the next few months will be a race against the virus.
content: As coronavirus infections surged around the country in early November — and as the prospect of a long, dark winter loomed — it was not clear if any of the vaccines in development would pan out.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Rosa
title: After the Storm, New York Digs Its Way Out
description: The city was covered in 17 inches of snow after one of the heaviest winter storms in recent history.
content: [Want to get New York Today by email? Here’s the sign-up.]
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Fandos
title: More than 370 congressional aides call for Trump’s conviction.
description: WASHINGTON — More than 370 Democratic congressional aides issued an unusual public appeal on Wednesday, imploring senators — in some cases their own bosses — to convict former President Donald J. Trump for inciting a violent “attack on our workplace” that threatened the peaceful transition of power.
content: WASHINGTON — More than 370 Democratic congressional aides issued an unusual public appeal on Wednesday, imploring senators — in some cases their own bosses — to convict former President Donald J. Trump for inciting a violent “attack on our workplace” that threatened the peaceful transition of power.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Fortini
title: A Breakout Portrait Artist Invested in Asian Representation
description: Entirely self-taught, Jiab Prachakul has spent over a decade honing her practice and its purpose. Now, she’s gotten her first big show.
content: A little more than 14 years ago, the Thai-born, Lyon-based artist Jiab Prachakul went to the National Portrait Gallery in London to see a David Hockney show. In the second room of the exhibition, she stood before “Mr. and Mrs. Clark and Percy” (1970-71) — Hockney’s famous painting of the fashion designer Ossie Clark, the textile designer Celia Birtwell and their pristine white cat — and had an epiphany. Prachakul, who had just left her job as a casting associate for an advertising production house, thought, “‘All the great artists, they are not great from the beginning. If you have the talent, you have to develop it.’ And that,” she recalls, when we meet via Zoom on a recent early morning in France and very early morning in America, “is when I thought, ‘I want to become an artist.’”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Finney Boylan
title: My Country Suddenly Turned on Me
description: Recovering from the trauma of the Trump era will depend on how its story is told.
content: Few moments of my life have taught me so much about America as the time my friend Franklin stabbed me with a pencil in 9th grade. This was in Ancient History class, where instead of listening to Mr. Dripps (his actual name) explain about the Hittites, I was doing an “imitation imitation” — you know, like an impression of Carol Channing imitating Jimmy Stewart.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Kirsch
title: Birthdays in Quarantine
description: How we’re celebrating.
content: Welcome. Take five minutes today and let The Times’s classical music writers and some of their favorite artists convince you to fall in love with string quartets. I spent my five with the musician and producer Rostam Batmanglij’s pick, the second movement of Ravel’s Quartet, an easy courtship.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gabe Cohn
title: Golden Globes 2021: A Full List of Nominees
description: Here are the films, television shows, actors and directors chosen by the Hollywood Foreign Press Association.
content: The 78th Golden Globe Awards are scheduled for Feb. 28 and will be shown on NBC. Amy Poehler and Tina Fey will return to host the ceremony, which they last led in 2015.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Szalai
title: Nearly 20 Million Americans Have a Felony Record. What Happens After They’ve Served Their Time?
description: In “Halfway Home,” Reuben Jonathan Miller draws on years of research and personal experience to write about how we understand incarceration and its afterlife.
content: There is, of course, the immediate experience of incarceration: the detention at any given moment of more than 2 million people in American jails and prisons, or what the sociologist Reuben Jonathan Miller calls “cages” — a word that captures the brute fact of confinement more vividly than the antiseptic vocabulary of “correctional facilities.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kyle Buchanan
title: Golden Globes Movies Snubs: ‘Da 5 Bloods’ and Meryl Streep Are Shut Out
description: Over all, Black-led dramas were snubbed. Among the surprise inclusions were Jared Leto for “The Little Things” and Kate Hudson for Sia’s “Music.”
content: With the Golden Globes, it’s best to expect the unexpected, and during an awards season this atypical, there’s an even higher chance of weird and wacky nominations. That’s why, though major movies like “Nomadland” and “The Trial of the Chicago 7” scored when the Golden Globe nominations were announced on Wednesday, it’s the out-of-left-field picks and startling exclusions that have everybody in Hollywood talking.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lara Jakes, Zolan Kanno-Youngs, Maggie Haberman and Michael D. Shear
title: Biden to Welcome More Refugees, but Far From All Will Get In
description: Gutted by the Trump administration, the refugee resettlement system is unable to quickly process tens of thousands of the world’s neediest people.
content: WASHINGTON — President Biden’s expected announcement on Thursday that he intends to allow more refugees into the United States this year will bring him face to face with a policy barrier left by his predecessor: a gutted resettlement system unable to quickly process the tens of thousands of desperate people whom Mr. Biden would like to let in.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Kliff
title: Some doctors, burned by low reimbursements, have stopped testing for the virus.
description: Across the United States, some doctors are seeing reimbursement rates so low that they do not cover the cost of the test supplies, jeopardizing access to a tool experts see as crucial to stopping the virus’s spread.
content: Across the United States, some doctors are seeing reimbursement rates so low that they do not cover the cost of the test supplies, jeopardizing access to a tool experts see as crucial to stopping the virus’s spread.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Caramanica
title: Ricky Powell, 59, Dies; Chronicled Early Hip-Hop and Downtown New York
description: Prolific with his point-and-shoot camera, he captured essential images of the Beastie Boys, Jean-Michel Basquiat, Run-DMC, Andy Warhol and more.
content: Ricky Powell, the downtown New York Zelig who with his point-and-shoot camera documented the early years of hip-hop’s ascendance as well as a host of other subcultural scenes and the celebrities and fringe characters who populated the city, was found dead on Monday in his West Village apartment. He was 59.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse McKinley and Luis Ferré-Sadurní
title: N.Y. Repeals Law That Critics Say Criminalized ‘Walking While Trans’
description: The anti-loitering law was designed to discourage street prostitution, but was viewed by L.G.B.T.Q. advocates as a cudgel to harass transgender people.
content: ALBANY, N.Y. — For decades, a state loitering law, originally designed to discourage street prostitution, was interpreted far more broadly, resulting in what civil rights advocates said was a pattern of police harassment of anyone who they viewed as looking different or suspicious.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Farhad Manjoo
title: Can We Please Stop Talking About Stocks, Please?
description: The stock market isn’t the economy, but that’s hard to remember in a bubble.
content: To hear more audio stories from publishers like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karen Weise and Daisuke Wakabayashi
title: How Andy Jassy, Amazon’s Next C.E.O., Was a ‘Brain Double’ for Jeff Bezos
description: Mr. Jassy, who will become Amazon’s chief this summer, has spent more than two decades absorbing lessons from Mr. Bezos.
content: SEATTLE — In 2002, Andy Jassy, a young executive at Amazon, began closely shadowing Jeff Bezos, the founder of the online bookstore.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeffrey Gettleman and Zia ur-Rehman
title: She Escaped Pakistan. Now Her Father Has Been Thrown Into Jail.
description: Mohammed Ismail, father of the women’s rights activist Gulalai Ismail, now faces harsh terrorism charges that critics say are about revenge, not justice.
content: NEW DELHI — Gulalai Ismail, one of Pakistan’s boldest human rights defenders and a stalwart critic of Pakistan’s security services, succeeded in escaping an enormous dragnet and making it to the United States in 2019, deeply humiliating the authorities who had been persecuting her.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Grose
title: Why Your Kid Wears Shorts in Winter
description: While you freeze in cold weather, they have a secret weapon.
content: The past three weekends, I have found myself shivering on the concrete of local playgrounds, because of my least favorite pandemic-related cultural change: outdoor children’s birthday parties in subarctic temperatures. I never thought I would miss the acrid smell of the dirty carpet at Brooklyn’s finest indoor bounce house emporium and mediocre pizza dispensary, but I really, really do. At least I didn’t have to wear a parka and two sweaters inside.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs and Michael D. Shear
title: Some Trump loyalists in the Dept. of Homeland Security could actively resist Biden’s immigration policies.
description: After a Texas judge last week temporarily blocked President Biden’s order to pause deportations for 100 days, immigration agents did not hesitate to use the brief window to defy the incoming president’s new tone.
content: After a Texas judge last week temporarily blocked President Biden’s order to pause deportations for 100 days, immigration agents did not hesitate to use the brief window to defy the incoming president’s new tone.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catie Edmondson
title: McCarthy condemns Marjorie Taylor Greene’s statements but declines to remove her from committees.
description: Representative Steny Hoyer said “it is clear there is no alternative to holding a floor vote on the resolution to remove Representative Greene from her committee assignments.”
content: Representative Kevin McCarthy, the top Republican, on Wednesday condemned Representative Marjorie Taylor Greene’s past conspiratorial and violent comments, but he declined to take any action against her on the eve of a vote forced by Democrats to remove her from congressional committees.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Holland Cotter and Roberta Smith
title: Art Gallery Shows to See Right Now
description: “Downtown 2021” pays homage to artists from more than two dozen galleries; Carmen Herrera’s Paris period reveals zigzag lines and textures.
content: New York City art galleries form a resilient and irrepressible ecosystem, one that has survived recessions, gentrification, at least one hurricane, and now an aggressive pandemic. Through everything, the system continues to sprout new life. The group show “Downtown 2021,” curated by the artist Sam Gordon, pays homage to this phenomenon by giving more than two dozen galleries their hardscrabble props.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘Please, Give Me Back My Daughter’
description: The remarkable story of one mother’s implausible quest to bring a cartel to justice for the murder of her child.
content: When her daughter Karen was kidnapped in 2014, Miriam Rodríguez knew exactly who was responsible: the Zetas, a cartel that ran organized crime in her town of San Fernando, Mexico.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth Chang
title: Jeff Bezos Renews Focus on Blue Origin, Which Has Been Slower to Launch
description: The Amazon founder started his private rocket company in 2000, but its busiest phase could just now be starting.
content: For most of its two decades of existence, Blue Origin was like Willy Wonka’s chocolate factory in the children’s book by Roald Dahl.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caleb Hampton
title: Biden Administration Faces Backlog of 380,000 Waiting to Immigrate
description: The suspension of most legal immigration, combined with the pandemic, has left visa applicants in limbo. Even if President Biden ends the bans, it could take years to process everyone.
content: When the pandemic forced her children’s school and day care to close, Luwam Beyene started working nights so she could be home during the day. As soon as she gets home, she makes breakfast and gets her son ready for online school. The children often have her attention until she leaves again for work in the evenings.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julian E. Barnes and Thomas Gibbons-Neff
title: U.S. Should Slow Withdrawal From Afghanistan, Bipartisan Panel Urges
description: A study group appointed by Congress finds that removing international forces by the May 1 date set in the 2020 U.S.-Taliban peace agreement could lead to a civil war in Afghanistan.
content: WASHINGTON — The Biden administration should slow the withdrawal of troops in Afghanistan, abandon the May 1 exit deadline and instead reduce American forces further only as security conditions improve, a congressionally appointed panel recommended Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Lyall
title: Scenes From a Marriage, Patinkin-Style
description: Mandy Patinkin and Kathryn Grody’s charming, irreverent pandemic-era posts led to unlikely social media stardom. Will the vaccine end their run?
content: Mandy Patinkin and Kathryn Grody have been together since their first date nearly 43 years ago, a giddy daylong romp through Greenwich Village that began with brunch and ended with them making out on a street corner. “I’m going to marry you,” he declared. “You’re going to get hurt, because I’m not going to marry anyone,” she replied.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maura Turcotte, Rachel Sherman and Derek M. Norman
title: In a first, a federal judge orders Oregon state prisons to vaccinate inmates.
description: A federal court judge in Oregon has ordered the state prison system to inoculate every inmate who wants to be vaccinated against Covid-19. The order, the first in the nation, comes as many states have declined to make vaccinating prisoners a priority, even though severe virus outbreaks inside prisons have been common.
content: A federal court judge in Oregon has ordered the state prison system to inoculate every inmate who wants to be vaccinated against Covid-19. The order, the first in the nation, comes as many states have declined to make vaccinating prisoners a priority, even though severe virus outbreaks inside prisons have been common.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Powell
title: I Miss a Lot of Things About the Office. My Breast Pump Isn’t One.
description: Working from home has made breastfeeding easier. Let’s hope the flexibility lasts even after the pandemic ends.
content: I miss my colleagues. I miss listening to podcasts during my morning commute. I miss water-cooler gossip. But you know what I don’t miss? My breast pump, the office lactation room, and most everything tied to being a nursing mom in the workplace.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rick Gladstone
title: U.N. Delays Salvage of Yemen Oil Tanker Amid Fears of Major Spill
description: The United Nations had planned to start a maritime salvage operation to prevent leaks from a dilapidated tanker holding four times the oil that spilled in the Exxon Valdez disaster. But Houthi insurgents have failed to provide a written security guarantee, the U.N. said.
content: The United Nations said Tuesday that it had indefinitely delayed an expedition to avert an ecological disaster from a crippled Yemeni tanker holding roughly 48 million gallons of oil, citing what the organization called a failure by Yemen’s Houthi insurgents to guarantee the salvage team’s safety in writing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Rosen
title: What’s in Your Prenatal Vitamin?
description: Doctors recommend them before, during and even after a pregnancy. But regulation is spotty and finding the right pill can be hard.
content: When I told my doctor that I was thinking of getting pregnant a few years ago, she advised me to start taking a prenatal vitamin right away. So I stopped by the grocery store on my way home and made for the supplement aisle. As I studied the array of options before me, I quickly grew overwhelmed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Wednesday Briefing
description: A Russian court sentences Aleksei Navalny.
content: A Moscow court sentenced Aleksei Navalny, President Vladimir Putin’s loudest critic, to more than two years in prison on Tuesday for violating parole from a 2014 suspended sentence by not checking in with the authorities, including while he was in Germany recovering from being poisoned in August. The decision is likely to send him to a far-flung penal colony for the first time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dani Blum
title: In the Vaccine Scramble, Cancer Patients Are Left Behind
description: Those with compromised immune systems are often advised to get the shots under medical supervision, but their cancer centers can’t always provide them.

content: The fiberglass skiff Lazora idled on the darkened Pacific Ocean a few miles south of American waters. It was roughly 25 feet long and seven feet wide, unlit, overloaded and offering no shelter from the elements. Twenty people were crammed aboard. Most were seated on narrow benches. A few huddled on the vomit-splattered deck. Some had opened slits in plastic garbage bags and pushed heads and arms through, flimsy protection against the damp October chill. Few life jackets were visible. At the boat’s stern, two Mexican men tended a 200-horsepower outboard engine and 10 plastic barrels of fuel. They were in the final hour of ferrying a load of undocumented migrants toward American land, in waters nearly three-quarters of a mile deep: human smugglers, running a boat through a seam where black sea met black sky.
